document_data.name: Ballads and Lore of One Dusty Road
document_data.author: [[Sharanralee Crownstar]]
document_data.mainbody:
'''''Ballads and Lore of One Dusty Road''''' was a work of two volumes penned by [[Sharanralee Crownstar]], a renowned adventuress and secretly a [[Harper]] agent in the mid-14{{th}} century [[DR]].

{{quote|''A woman, or a man, may come to hold many treasures in life. [[Gold]], [[gem]]s, a good name, lovers, good friends, influence, high rank–all of these are of value. All of these most covet. But of them all the most valuable, I tell ye, are friends good and true. Have these, and ye will scarce notice the lack if ye never win aught else.''|Excerpt from ''Ballads and Lore of One Dusty Road''}}
document_data.Contents: ''[[Lost and Away]]'' was a traditional [[elf]]in fireside ballad sang by the [[Fair Folk]] recorded in ''Ballads and Lore of One Dusty Road''.{{cite web| url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160331145815/http://www.candlekeep.com/library/articles/sse/sse_101112-06.htm| title = So Saith Ed Oct – Dec 2006| accessdate = 25-11-2021| date = 25-11-2021}}
document_data.History: ''Ballads and Lore of One Dusty Road'' contained stories and musical works collected by Sharanralee Crownstar during her long adventuring career. The books also collected her musings, notable about the true value of friendships. The first volume was published in the {{YearlinkName|1337}},{{Cite web/The Candlekeep Collection}}
